Award.AwardTitle: Language Processing as Boundedly Optimal Control of Memory, Perception, and Action

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Language comprehension, whether listening or reading, is a rapid skill that requires the coordination of perception (e.g., recognizing printed words on a page), action (e.g., controlling the movement of the eyes), memory (e.g. remembering what came in earlier parts of a sentence to relate them to later parts), and linguistic knowledge (e.g., using the order of words to constrain possible relations among them). Understanding how these processes are combined on a moment-to-moment basis has been a major challenge for cognitive science. This project will develop and test a new theory of language comprehension from an adaptive perspective. The hypothesis is that language processing may be understood as the coordinated, adaptive control of both internal (and limited) cognitive processes and external perceptual-motor actions so as to maximize specific task goals. To apply this idea to language, the investigators will formalize and implement optimal control models of limited Bayesian perception and memory for different reading tasks. These Bounded Optimal Control models will generate predictions that will be tested by monitoring the eye-movements and responses of humans.

Bounded Optimal Control is a new approach to language, thought, and action, with possibly major long-term implications for how we understand and address individual differences and deficits in reading ability. It represents a shift in scientific focus from seeking to describe the perceptual and cognitive strategies that the mind and brain employ during reading, to specifying clearly the problems for which these strategies are the solutions. There is no canonical strategy because there is no canonical problem. Thus, the best cognitive and perceptual strategies are determined by specific task goals and individual constraints. This has the potential to change our approach to reading deficits: rather than asking how an individual's reading strategies deviate from normal, it is possible to ask instead whether those strategies are the best possible strategies, taking into account both task goals and idiosyncratic cognitive constraints. Revealing the true nature of the gaps between actual behavior and "bounded optimal" behavior is an important step in understanding how to go about closing them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has produced two sets of significant outcomes.   The first major outcome is a new and formally rigorous theoretical approach that helps us understand how people make rational use of bounded perception (such as foveated vision) and bounded memory (such as a very limited short term or working memory) in reading, visual attention, and rapid decision making.  The approach differs from a common approach in the behavioral sciences, which is to measure human behavior against a benchmark of perfect rationality or optimal performance, and then to create theories of limited cognitive mechanisms that might explain why behavior falls short of that benchmark. In contrast, the approach developed in this project, called computational rationality, asks:  How would a rational person accomplish some task given that they have certain well-established bounds on cognition and perception?  Such questions can be rigorously formulated as precise computational problems. The solutions to these problems tell us not what a perfect unbounded agent would do, but what a computationally rational agent would do (and so the approach is one way  to understand what the Nobel laureate Herbert Simon called "bounded rationality").

The second major set of project outcomes arose from testing and applying the new theoretical approach to a set of specific phenomena in language, cognition, and perception.  In particular, we have applied the approach to understanding how people move their eyes in reading, and while searching for a visual target among distractors.  An important theoretical discovery is that very detailed predictions of eye-movement behavior can be derived from a small set of simple assumptions about bounds on visual perception and the time it takes the brain to send control signals to the muscles that move the eyes.  An important empirical finding is that people adaptively fine-tune their eye-movements at the millisecond level in order to maximize performance in reading tasks. These findings together are contributing to a shift in the field of psycholinguistics away from understanding the details of language processing in terms of fixed cognitive mechanisms, and toward an understanding grounded in adaptation–but adaptation to both external demands and internal cognitive limitations.

In the arena of decision making, we have produced new explanations of a class of phenomena called "preference reversals" that have previously been taken to be clear violations of rationality.  A preference reversal in decision making occurs when a preference for one option over another is reversed by the addition of further options (e.g., choosing A when offered A, B and C, but choosing B when offered A, B, and D).  It has been argued that preference reversals are evidence that people violate principles of rationality.  Our new theory offers a different perspective:  It shows  that preference reversals are exactly what should be expected from a decision maker who is rationally adapting to very basic and uncontroversial bounds on perception and cognition.           

Overall, these theoretical results and empirical findings contribute to a new understanding of how human behavior is shaped by our cognitive and perceptual limitations–an understanding that emphasizes how we adapt rationally not only to our external environmental demands, but to our own cognitive bounds. The most significant potential broader impact of this new understanding concerns how we might analyze and accommodate the individual differences in cognition and perception that lead to differences in language and decision making abilities.  More specifically, the science produced in this project should lead to a better understanding of individual differences in reading, including severe reading deficits, as well as changes due to age-related changes in perception and cognition. By having rigorous and tested cognitive theories that directly take into account the brain's adaptation to its own processing bounds, we will have a better basis for developing interventions that facilitate the mitigation of these bounds.
